slides.title: The Project
slides.desc: You need an audio-narrated slideshow for your docs
slides.example: 26 slides, TTS integration, ~500 lines of code
slides.script: Here's the challenge. You're adding an interactive audio tour to your documentation‚Äîexactly like the one you're experiencing right now. Twenty-six slides with text-to-speech narration. About 500 lines of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Which Claude tool should you use?

slides.title: The Question
slides.desc: Claude Pro, Claude Code, or Claude API?
slides.example: Each has different pricing and workflow
slides.script: You have three options. Claude Pro at twenty dollars a month with message limits. Claude Code, a VS Code extension with API pricing. Or the Claude API for direct integration. Each has trade-offs. Let's figure out which makes sense.

slides.title: Requirements Gathering
slides.desc: What exactly do you need to build?
slides.example: HTML structure, CSS styling, JavaScript for audio
slides.script: First, let's understand the scope. You need HTML structure for the slides. CSS for styling and animations. JavaScript to handle audio playback, navigation, and text-to-speech. That's three files minimum, probably more.

slides.title: Token Math Basics
slides.example: ~50 tokens per line of code
slides.script: Here's how pricing works. Roughly 50 tokens per line of code. Your 500 lines equals about 25,000 tokens. But that's just the code output. You also need context‚Äîthe requirements, examples, documentation you provide. That adds another 30,000 tokens of input.

slides.title: Claude Pro Economics
slides.example: $20-200/month depending on tier
slides.script: Claude Pro has tiers. Twenty dollars a month for the base plan, but you'll hit message limits quickly on real work. A hundred or two hundred dollars gets higher limits. But limits still exist‚Äînot truly unlimited. You can exhaust even expensive tiers.

slides.title: Claude Code Economics
slides.desc: Pay per token, but automated workflow
slides.example: ~$0.92 for this project with 3 iterations
slides.script: Claude Code uses API pricing. For this project, with three iterations, you're looking at about 92 cents total. Way cheaper than Pro if you know what you want. Plus it edits files directly‚Äîsaves time and eliminates the copy-paste errors that waste hours.

slides.title: Claude API Economics
slides.example: Same ~$0.92, but fastest workflow
slides.script: The API has the same token pricing as Code, but you write the integration yourself. If you already have API infrastructure set up, this is the fastest option. Perfect for automation and scale. But it requires upfront development work.

slides.title: The First Iteration
slides.example: Slide HTML, basic CSS, simple navigation
slides.script: Let's walk through iteration one. You need the slide container, basic styling, and navigation buttons. You paste in your requirements. Claude generates the code. You test it. Works, but needs refinement. This is where the workflow differences emerge.

slides.title: Iteration Two: Polish
slides.example: Smooth transitions, responsive design, accessibility
slides.script: Iteration two is about polish. Smooth slide transitions. Responsive design for mobile. Proper accessibility with ARIA labels. With Pro, you iterate freely but risk hitting message limits. With Code, each iteration costs tokens but you see changes immediately in your editor.

slides.title: Iteration Three: Audio
slides.example: Browser TTS, playback controls, sync with slides
slides.script: Iteration three adds the audio. Browser text-to-speech isn't trivial. You need playback controls, speed adjustment, synchronization with slide changes. This might take several attempts to get right. Pro users can experiment but might hit limits. API users pay predictably per attempt.

slides.title: Multi-Language Support
slides.example: English, Portuguese, Hindi, Spanish, Chinese‚Äîdifferent voices
slides.script: Here's where it gets interesting. You want multi-language support. Same slides, different TTS voices for each language. This requires careful architecture. The browser needs to select the right voice for each locale. Testing across languages takes time and iterations.

slides.title: Time Reality Check
slides.example: Promised 2.5hrs ‚Üí Actually 6hrs
slides.script: Let's be honest about time. AI tools promise faster development. But reality is messy. Our actual case study took six hours with multiple context losses and failures. Not the two and a half hours estimated. Budget real time, not ideal time.

slides.title: Cost Reality Check
slides.example: Your time √ó hourly rate + frustration
slides.script: Real cost isn't just the subscription or API fees. It's your time. Six hours of developer time at a hundred dollars an hour is six hundred dollars. The 92-cent API cost is irrelevant compared to your time cost. Choose tools that save time, not just money.

slides.title: The Learning Curve
slides.example: Pro: Hours | Code: Days | API: Weeks
slides.script: Each tool has a learning curve. Claude Pro is a chat interface‚Äîlearn it in hours. Claude Code requires VS Code familiarity‚Äîtakes days to master. The API requires programming skills and infrastructure‚Äîweeks to set up properly. Factor learning time into your choice.

slides.title: Context Loss Problem
slides.desc: When AI forgets your project mid-stream
slides.example: Hit limits ‚Üí New session ‚Üí Re-explain everything
slides.script: Here's a brutal reality with Pro. You hit message limits. Start a new session. Claude has zero memory of your project. You re-explain everything. Lost context means lost time. This happened three times in our case study. With Code, your files persist. The context is the codebase.

slides.title: The Hallucination Problem
slides.desc: When AI insists it did something it didn't
slides.example: Claude: I updated the file | You: No you didn't
slides.script: Another Pro problem. Claude might insist it updated a file. You check‚Äînothing changed. It hallucinated the action. With Code, files actually change. You see the diff. No ambiguity. No gaslighting. The file system is the source of truth.

slides.title: When Pro Actually Wins
slides.example: Should we use cards or carousel? What about layout?
slides.script: Claude Pro excels at exploration. Trying different approaches. Debating architecture. Asking what-if questions. This thinking phase has real value. Our six hours of planning was actually Pro's strength‚Äîiterative design thinking without cost anxiety per question.

slides.title: When Code/Cursor Wins
slides.example: Direct editing beats copy-paste every time
slides.script: For actual implementation, Claude Code or Cursor with Claude dominates. Direct file editing. Immediate feedback. No copy-paste errors. When you know what you're building, these tools are five times faster than Pro's chat interface.

slides.title: When API Wins
slides.example: 10 slides ‚Üí 10,000 slides programmatically
slides.script: The API wins at scale. Need to generate a thousand variations? Automate it. No human clicking. No per-message limits. Just programmatic generation. If you're doing repetitive work at scale, the API is the only sane choice.

slides.title: The Real Math
slides.example: Monthly subscription ‚â† One-time project cost
slides.script: Let's be honest about the comparison. Twenty dollars a month for Pro covers all your work that month. The 92 cents is just for this one project. They're not directly comparable. Pro is a gym membership. API is buying a single protein bar. Different models for different needs.

slides.title: Phase-Based Selection
slides.example: Explore ‚Üí Implement ‚Üí Scale
slides.script: Smart developers use multiple tools. Explore architecture in Pro. Implement features in Code. Automate at scale with API. Each phase has an optimal tool. Don't force one tool for everything. Match the tool to the task.

slides.title: Project Size Thresholds
slides.example: Small: Any tool | Large: Must use multiple
slides.script: Project size determines flexibility. A six-hour project? Maybe stay in one tool. A hundred-hour project? You must use the right tool for each phase or waste massive time and money. Scale determines strategy.

slides.title: AI Strengths
slides.example: Math, logic, data processing > Layout design
slides.script: Know the tool's strengths. Claude is amazing at math, logic, algorithms, and data transformation. Terrible at visual design and layout from scratch. Give Claude a reference design to copy‚Äîit works. Ask it to design something beautiful‚Äîit fails. Use it for what it's good at.

slides.title: AI Weaknesses
slides.example: Aesthetic judgment, spatial thinking, novel architecture
slides.script: Claude struggles with aesthetics. Spatial layout. Novel architecture outside its training. Fresh ideas that don't match common patterns. These require human creativity. AI assists best when augmenting human judgment, not replacing it.

slides.title: The Honest Recommendation
slides.example: Start with Pro, learn patterns, then optimize
slides.script: Here's the honest advice. If you're new, start with Claude Pro. Learn what good output looks like. Understand the patterns. Then graduate to Code for implementation. Use API when you need scale. Don't optimize prematurely. Learn first, optimize later.

slides.title: Your Next Steps
slides.desc: Take action on what you learned
slides.example: Try all three tools on a small project
slides.script: Your homework. Take a small project. Try it in Claude Pro to explore. Then implement in Claude Code. Compare the experience. You'll know immediately which workflow fits your brain. Direct experience beats any guide. Go build something.
